title: 114_hr3445
content: The Act may be cited as "The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry (BICI) Accountability Act of 2015". The Kingdom of Bahrain is a party to international human rights instruments, citizens intensified calls for government reform in 2011, leading to the establishment of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry (BICI) in July 2011. The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry (BICI) was established in July 2011 to investigate human rights violations in Bahrain in February/March 2011. The BICI received 9,000 complaints and conducted over 5,000 interviews, submitting a 503-page report to the Government of Bahrain on November 23, 2011. The BICI report, submitted to the Government of Bahrain on November 23, 2011, included 26 recommendations for administrative and legal actions, as well as mechanisms to prevent similar events. The King of Bahrain pledged to implement reforms for national reconciliation. The Department of State noted progress in implementing BICI recommendations but highlighted the country's increasing polarization and the need for further work. The Department of State reported to Congress that only 5 out of 26 recommendations from the BICI report on Bahrain had been fully implemented. The report found that the Bahrain Defence Force was involved in implementing a decree declaring a State of National Safety, with units carrying out arrests, including of doctors and former parliamentarians. Human Rights First found no accountability for excessive violence by Bahrain Defence Force against protesters since 2011. Amnesty International labeled Ali Salman a prisoner of conscience sentenced to four years in an unfair trial. Bahrain summoned opposition leader Khalil al-Marzooq for investigation into insulting a ministry and inciting hatred. Americans for Democracy and Human Rights in Bahrain reported the re-arrest of individuals by the Bahraini government. The Government of Bahrain re-arrested opposition leader Ibrahim Sharif for criticizing the government and calling for political reform. The Department of State's 2014 Human Rights Report on Bahrain highlighted issues such as arbitrary arrests, torture, lack of due process, and harsh sentences for activists. The decision to lift holds on security assistance was announced on June 29, 2015. The decision to lift holds on security assistance to the Bahrain Defence Force and National Guard was made following Bahrain's crackdown on demonstrations in 2011. The US Government is prohibited from selling certain arms to Bahrain until the Government fully implements recommendations from the 2011 Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry report. Prohibited items include tear gas, small arms, light weapons, ammunition, Humvees, and other crowd control items.
